metadata.title: Manganese porphines-NH<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf>@SBA-15 as heterogeneous catalytic systems with homogeneous behavior: Effect of length of linker in immobilized manganese porphine catalysts in oxidation of olefins

Table 3 Entry Catalyst Co-catalyst (mmol) Conversion% 1 Long-chain@Mn(TCPP)OAc – 43 2 Long-chain@Mn(TCPP)OAc 0.079 59 3 Long-chain@Mn(TCPP)OAc 0.12 67 4 Long-chain@Mn(TCPP)OAc 0.16 70 5 Long-chain@Mn(TCPP)OAc 0.23 70 6 Short-chain@Mn(TCPP)OAc – 34 7 Short-chain@Mn(TCPP)OAc 0.16 49 Manganese porphines-NH2@SBA-15 as heterogeneous catalytic systems with homogeneous behavior: Effect of length of linker in immobilized manganese porphine catalysts in oxidation of olefins Saeed Rayati a ⁎ Zahra Sheybanifard a Mostafa M. Amini b Azam Aliakbari b a Department of Chemistry, K.N. Toosi University of Technology, P.O. Box 16315-1618, 15418 Tehran, Iran Department of Chemistry K.N. Toosi University of Technology P.O. Box 16315-1618 Tehran 15418 Iran b Department of Chemistry, Shahid Behesti University, Tehran, Iran Department of Chemistry Shahid Behesti University Tehran Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Two types of SBA-15 mesoporous silica were functionalized with different nitrogen-carbon chain lengths (long and short-chain) and then used as solid supports for immobilization of manganese(III) complex of meso-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphine, [SBA-15-short-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] and [SBA-15-long-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc]. The prepared catalysts were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), FT-IR and UV–vis spectroscopy. The loading of catalyst onto porous materials was determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy. Thermal analysis also demonstrated that the immobilized catalysts are thermally stable up to almost 400°C. A comparative study based on the difference in chain length of the functional groups of SBA-15 in the oxidation of olefins was carried out in the presence of urea hydrogen peroxide (UHP) as oxidant and acetic anhydride as an activator. The novel long-chain catalyst was designed to improve performance of the catalytic activity. Keywords Long-chain catalyst Heterogeneous catalytic system Mn-porphine Oxidation Olefins 1 Introduction In order to achieve useful and practical intermediates and products, metal complexes have been considered as catalysts for the oxidation of various compounds. Meanwhile, the development of approaches for designing efficient catalytic systems has attracted much interest in recent years [1]. Even though the homogeneous catalytic systems are often more effective than the heterogeneous analogues, the difficulties in separation of the catalyst is the disadvantage of them and therefore the researchers are interested to design and construct more effective heterogeneous catalytic systems. Synthetic metalloporphines as model catalysts for cytochrome P450 have been extensively studied for oxidation of variety compounds using various oxidizing agents [2–8]. However, the oxidative degradation of these valuable macromolecules is often encountered in the oxidation reactions [9]. Therefore, immobilization of the metalloporphine complexes onto solid supports such as mesoporous materials with high specific surface area, make them stable toward degradation [10–18]. The supporting of the large metal complexes such as metalloporphines through an organic spacer onto the mesoporous materials is often preferred and also, the solidity of the attachment to the support is an important factor that should be considered during immobilization process [10,19]. Among different mesoporous silica, Santa Barbara Amorphous (SBA-15) due to its unique properties such as thick walls (4–6nm), thermal and mechanical stability, highly ordered mesostructure, large specific surface area (above 1000m2/g) and regular 2D hexagonal array of channels with a narrow pore-size distribution of 1.5–300Å has attracted more attentions as solid support [17,20–23]. The functionalization and modification of SBA-15 could enhance its capability as a support for supporting the large metal complexes such as metalloporphines. On the other hand, covalent immobilization of the catalyst, decrease catalyst leaching during catalytic reactions [24–29]. In the present study, we have utilized two types of functionalized SBA-15 with 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane and N-(3-trimethoxysilylpropyl)diethylenetriamine which have short and long chain lengths relative to the surface of support and then a Mn-complex of meso-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphine (H2TCPP) has been covalently anchored onto them, [(SBA-15-short-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] and [SBA-15-long-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc)]. Hydrogen peroxide and its derivatives are well-known as green oxidants which extensively used in the oxidation of various compounds [30,31]. One of the methods for the activation of hydrogen peroxide and its derivatives is the formation of peroxycarboxylic acids from the reaction of carboxcylic acid anhydrides and H2O2 [30,32]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and physico-chemical characterization techniques The chemicals, reagents and solvents were purchased from Aldrich, Merck or Fluka chemical companies and were employed without further purification. The electronic absorption spectra were recorded on PerkinElmer Lambda 25 UV–vis spectrophotometer. The mesoporous materials and heterogenous catalytic systems were identified by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) using a STOE diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ=0.15418nm) at 40kV and 40mA. The diffraction patterns were recorded in the Bragg angle (theta) range from 0.5° to 10° for small angle XRD with a position sensitive detector using a step size of 0.06°. Infrared spectra were recorded (KBr pellets) on an ABB Bomem: FTLA 2000-100 in the range of 400–4000cm−1. Thermal analysis (TGA/DTA) was carried out on a Bahr STA-503 instrument in air at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. Gas chromatography experiments (GC) were performed with a Shimadzu GC–14B equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) with a SAB-5 capillary column (phenyl methyl siloxane 30m×320mm×0.25mm). A Varian AA 240 atomic absorption spectrometer was used for manganese determination. 2.2 General procedure for the preparation of porphine and metalloporphine H2TCPP was prepared by refluxing 4-carboxybenzaldehyde (300mg, 2mmol) and pyrrole (0.12mL, 1.8mmol) in propionic acid as described by Adler et al. [33] and then, Mn(TCPP)OAc was prepared according to the literature [34]. 2.3 General procedure for the preparation of 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane and N-(3-trimethoxysilylpropyl)diethylenetriamine functionalized SBA-15 (SBA-15-short-chain-NH2 and SBA-15-long-chain-NH2) SBA-15 nanoporous silica was prepared according to previous reports [35]. The SBA-15 nanoporous was functionalized using general procedure used for functionalization of silica using silane coupling agent [36]. In a typical reaction, 1.0g of SBA-15 was suspended in 50mL toluene and the mixture was stirred for 1h, then 2.0mL of 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane[(C2H5O)3Si-(CH2)3NH2, Aldrich, USA]or N-(3-Trimethoxysilylpropyl)diethylenetriamine [(CH3O)3Si-(CH2)3NH(CH2)2NH(CH2)2NH2, Aldrich, USA] was added to the mixture and refluxed for 24h. The white solid was then removed from the solvent by filtration and washed with ethanol and then dried at room temperature. 2.4 General procedure for the preparation of heterogeneous catalytic systems [SBA-15-short-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc],[SBA-15-long-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] Synthesis of heterogenized catalysts was carried out according to the method described in the literature [9,19,30]. 2-(1H-benzotriazole-1-yl)-1,1,3,3-tetramethyluronium tetrafluoroborate (TBTU) (400mg) and N,N′-diisopropylamine(DIPEA) (300mg) were added to a mixture of short or/and long chain functionalized SBA-15 (400mg) and Mn(TCPP)OAc (100mg) in 25mL dichloromethane and then this mixturewas stirred for 48h at room temperature. In order to remove the weakly adsorbed metalloporphines on the mesoporous surface, the solid residue was finally washed with dichloromethane until the filtrate became colorless and then, dried at room temperature. 2.5 General procedure for catalytic oxidation of olefins In a typical procedure, catalytic experiments were carried out in a 5mL test tube containing 6.39×10−4 mmol of catalyst (7.07×10−7 g of Mn(TCPP)OAc per 1g catalyst), 0.16mmol of imidazole as co-catalyst and 0.064mmol of olefins in a mixture of dichloromethane and methanol (1mL, 1:1) as solvent. The oxidation reaction was initiated by adding the UHP (0.089mmol) and then acetic anhydride (0.3mmol), under magnetic stirring at room temperature. The heterogenized catalyst was then filtered, and the organic phase was analyzed by gas chromatography and the oxidation products were identified by comparison with authentic samples. The reusability of heterogeneous catalytic systems was checked in the multiple consecutive oxidation of 4-methyl styrene as described above. At the end of each reaction, the catalyst was separated and washed with methanol and dichloromethane and then, dried at 60°C for 24h before reuse. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizationof the heterogeneous catalytic systems[(SBA-15-short-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] and [SBA-15-long-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc)] The heterogenized catalysts were synthesized using TBTU (2-(1H-benzotriazole-1-yl)-1,1,3,3-tetramethyluronium tetrafluoroborate) as a highly effective uronium salt that has been used as an coupling reagent in the presence of DIPEA (N,N′-diisopropylamine) for the preparation of amidic bonds (Scheme 1 ). The manganese content of the heterogenized catalysts was determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy which showed loadings of 0.24 and 0.46mmol/g of the catalyst for the long-chain (2.6×10−4 g of Mn(TCPP)OAc per 1g catalyst) and short-chain (5.09×10−4 g of Mn(TCPP)OAc per 1g catalyst) catalysts, respectively. The immobilization of manganese porphine onto mesoporous materials was evaluated using FT-IR spectra (Fig. 1 ). The FT-IR spectra of functionalized porous materials (short and long-chain) shows two bands at 1064 and 1090cm−1, which are attributed to the stretching vibrations of Si-O-Si and also the bands at 796 and 784cm−1 are assigned to the stretching vibrations of Si-OH. The strong bands at 3444 and 3460cm−1 confirmed the presence of amine groups (Fig. 1 a and b). In the FT-IR spectra of [SBA-15-short-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] and [SBA-15-long-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] a broad band at 3470 and 3446cm−1 are attributed to the amidic bond constructed between functionalized porous materials and Mn-porphine (Fig. 1 c and d) [37]. The similarity between FT-IR spectra of functionalized porous materials and heterogenized catalysts indicates that the porous nature of the amine-SBA-15 has been kept after immobilizing the metalloporphine complexes onto them. Existence of the porphine in the mesoporous materials was confirmed by comparison of the UV–vis spectra of functionalized amine-SBA-15, [SBA-15-long-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] and [SBA-15-short-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] (Fig. 2 ). The UV–vis spectra of functionalized porous materials (long and short-chain) were similar (Fig. 2 c and d). The absorption spectrum of Mn(TCPP)OAc in DMF exhibits a sharp band at 470nm (Soret band) and two weak absorptions at 566nm and 601nm (Q bands) [19]. These bands were remaining when the Mn-porphine was anchored onto the functionalized porous materials (Fig. 2 a and b). The low-angle X-ray diffraction pattern of functionalized amine-SBA-15 showed that the nanoporous structure of silica after functionalization remains intact (Fig. 3 ). The characteristic diffraction peak (d100) of mesoporous materials is at about 1.41° (Fig. 3 c and d) [38]. This diffraction peak was also observed after anchoring of Mn-porphine onto functinalized amine-SBA-15. A slight shift to a lower angle and lower intensity is due to a decrease in the mesoscopic order of the materials and mainly due to the contrast matching between the silicate framework and organic moieties located inside the porous materials channels (Fig. 3 a and b) [17,39]. The thermal behavior of long-chain and short-chain catalysts is also illustrated in Fig. 4 which shows thermal stability of heterogenized catalysts up to 400°C. According to the results, the degradation of catalyst has been occurred between 400 and 500°C. 3.2 Catalytic oxidation of olefins The catalytic efficiency of [SBA-15-short-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] and [SBA-15-long-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] as heterogenized catalysts was compared in the oxidation of cyclooctene as a model substrate with urea hydrogen peroxide (UHP) as oxygen donor and acetic anhydride as activator and the influence of various parameters such as nature of solvent, amount of co-catalyst, activator and oxidant has been evaluated. In order to investigate the catalytic performance of the prepared catalysts, a blank experiment was also performed and the result showed that the presence of catalyst is indispensable for an efficient catalytic reaction and in the absence of the heterogenized catalysts only 20% cyclooctene oxide was obtained after 3h. Also, in the presence of funectinalized-SBA-15-NH2 as catalyst no significant conversion was observed (13%). In reactions catalyzed by metalloporphines, the conversion values and product yields are usually influenced by the nature of solvent [40]. Methanol and dichloromethane were chosen as the reaction media for oxidation of cyclooctene with UHP and acetic anhydride in the presence of [SBA-15-long-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] as heterogenized catalyst and a mixture of MeOH and CH2Cl2 (1:1) was found to be the best one (Table 1 ). At this mixture of solvent, short-chain catalyst showed lower reactivity toward oxidation of cyclooctene in comparison with long-chain catalyst (Table 1, entries 3 and 4). The results show that in the absence of an activator, the reaction do not proceed and acetic anhydride was found to be an effective activator for both catalysts and also the effect of the amount of acetic anhydride was inspected (Table 2 ). The results showed that the oxidation reaction needs 0.3mmol (3.5 equimolar amount of acetic anhydride with respect to the UHP) acetic anhydride for the highest conversion in the presence of [SBA-15-long-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] as catalyst. On the other hand, running the oxidation reaction by [SBA-15-short-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] as catalyst led to a conversion of 49% (Table 2, entry 8). Therefore, long-chain catalyst has been found to show higher catalytic activity in the oxidation of cyclooctene with 0.3mmol acetic anhydride compared to short-chain catalyst. The catalytic activity of the heterogenized catalysts was also evaluated with UHP and acetic acid as activator (Table 2, entries 9 and 10). The results show that the reaction precedes only 6% and 3% with long-chain and short-chain catalysts, respectively. In Fig. 5 the effect of UHP:cyclooctene molar ratio in the oxidation of cyclooctene in the presence of long-chain catalyst is shown. Interestingly, cyclooctene conversion raised with increasing the UHP:cyclooctene molar ratio to 1.4 and this increase in conversion turns into a decrease beyond this ratio. The influence of nitrogenous bases as co-catalyst in the oxidative reactions with metalloporphines has been usually checked [41–43]. Here, the oxidation of cyclooctene was carried out using various amounts of imidazole as co-catalyst (Table 3 ) and 1.6×10−4 mol was found to be optimized one in the presence of long-chain catalyst as catalyst (Table 3, entry 4). In addition, the catalytic activity of short-chain catalyst was probed with and without imidazole (Table 3, entries 6 and 7). The results showed when the imidazole was omitted from the reaction mixture, 43% and 34% conversions were obtained for long-chain and short-chain catalysts, respectively (Table 3, entries 1 and 6) and then upon addition of imidazole, long-chain catalyst showed higher catalytic activity in comparison with short-chain one. On the other hand, addition of more imidazole to the reaction mixture (2.3×10−4 mol) led to no change in conversion (Table 3, entry 5). In order to compare homogeneous catalytic system (Mn(TCPP)OAc) with heterogeneous catalytic systems, the oxidation of cyclooctene was also done in the same condition and the formation of 73% cyclooctene oxide was observed (Fig. 6 ). According to these results, the presence a long chain in the structure of long-chain catalyst led to the higher catalytic activity as homogeneous one. Hence, using of long-chain catalyst leads to dual advantages: the high catalytic activity as a homogeneous catalytic system and same time benefit of convenient separation which the homogeneous complex cannot be recovered even once, the heterogenized catalysts can be separated and reused for a similar reaction. [SBA-15-long-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] and [SBA-15-short-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] are also efficient heterogenized catalysts for oxidation of various olefins under the optimized reaction conditions and the results are presented in Fig. 7 . The long-chain catalyst has been found to show higher catalytic activity in oxidation of various olefins compared to the short-chain one. In both catalytic systems, the oxidation of cyclooctene (70% long-chain and 49% short-chain), cyclohexene (65% long-chain and 52% short-chain), styrene (68% long-chain and 64% short-chain), 4-chloro styrene (57% long-chain and 56% short-chain) and 4-methoxy styrene (96% long-chain and 94% short-chain) give epoxide as the sole product at room temperature after 3h of reaction time but in the oxidation of α-methyl styrene (79% long-chain and 74% short-chain) and 4-methyl styrene (86% long-chain and 81% short-chain), acetophenone and 4-methyl benzaldehyde are also formed as the minor product, respectively. Apparently, due to the steric hindrance of methyl substituent, α-methyl styrene is less reactive than styrene towards epoxidation reaction. Indene was also oxidized in 73% and 56% yields in the presence of long-chain and short-chain catalyst, respectively. In the case of terminal olefins such as 1-octene (7% long-chain and 5% short-chain) the corresponding epoxide was also detected as the sole product. After 6h of reaction time, the catalytic activity of long-chain catalyst was also superior in comparison with the Short-chain one. The results show that about styrene and substituted styrenes, there is lower difference between the catalytic activity of long-chain and short-chain one. For studying catalyst reuse and stability, 4-methyl styrene was chosen as a model substrate and the reactions were run as described in experimental section (Fig. 8 ). For each reaction, the catalyst was separated, washed with MeOH and CH2Cl2 three times and dried before being used. The results showed that the yield of the catalytic activity reach to 48% and 46% for long-chain and short-chain catalyst, respectively after using the catalysts for five consecutive times. As it can be seen, the short-chain catalyst in comparison with long-chain catalyst showed a rapid decrease in the first cycle while such reduction was observed in the second cycle for long-chain catalyst. Nevertheless, both catalysts can be use for several times and this is a good result for a heterogeneous catalytic system. 3.3 Proposed catalytic mechanism In the absence of acetic anhydride, the oxidation of olefins with UHP and heterogeneous catalytic systems did not proceed (Table 2, entry 1) but as mentioned above, in the presence of acetic anhydride and UHP without catalysts (blank experiment) a conversion of ca. 20% was obtained. These observations suggest a catalytic cycle containing peracetic acid formed by the reaction of UHP and acetic anhydride (Scheme 2 , I) [30,32,44]. In the presence of catalysts, addition of acetic anhydride resulted in an increase in the catalytic activity. It seems that formed peracetic acid (I) can be coordinate to the Mn-center (Scheme 2, II) and then oxygen transfer to the olefins will occur. This intermediate (Scheme 2 II) can either undergo heterolytic and/or homolytic cleavage of O–O bond and could produce a manganese-oxo intermediate (Scheme 2, III) as a result of homolytic cleavage of O–O bond and afterwards, olefins as a nucleophile will attack to the oxygen atom and epoxide product will be formed by direct oxygenation [45–49]. On the other hand, this intermediate could produce another manganese-oxo intermediate (Scheme 2, IV) as a result of heterolytic cleavage of O–O bond and a radical mechanism can be occurred through H abstraction from olefins or water. However, both intermediates can be active oxidant. 4 Conclusions The catalytic activity of Mn(TCPP)OAc complexes immobilized onto the two types of functionalized SBA-15(NH2) was investigated in the oxidation of olefins. The results showed that the catalytic activity of the long-chain catalyst is higher than the short-chain one and also its catalytic performance is similar with homogeneous catalytic system. In this study, a mixture of CH2Cl2:MeOH(0.5:0.5) has been found to be the best solvent system. The results show that about styrene and substituted styrenes, there is lower difference between the catalytic activity of long-chain and short-chain one. However, in all these cases, the long-chain catalyst shows higher activity in comparison with short-chain one. Also, both catalysts can be reused and recovered at least four times. coredata.dc:description: Two types of SBA-15 mesoporous silica were functionalized with different nitrogen-carbon chain lengths (long and short-chain) and then used as solid supports for immobilization of manganese(III) complex of meso-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphine, [SBA-15-short-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc] and [SBA-15-long-chain-NH2@Mn(TCPP)OAc]. The prepared catalysts were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), FT-IR and UV–vis spectroscopy. The loading of catalyst onto porous materials was determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy. Thermal analysis also demonstrated that the immobilized catalysts are thermally stable up to almost 400°C. A comparative study based on the difference in chain length of the functional groups of SBA-15 in the oxidation of olefins was carried out in the presence of urea hydrogen peroxide (UHP) as oxidant and acetic anhydride as an activator. The novel long-chain catalyst was designed to improve performance of the catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Manganese porphines-NH2@SBA-15 as heterogeneous catalytic systems with homogeneous behavior: Effect of length of linker in immobilized manganese porphine catalysts in oxidation of olefins
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
